''The Foreign Assignment: An Incubator, or Exile?'' (Personal Business, Oct. 22), looked at the increasing demand for corporate globetrotters, and at the possible problems these workers encounter.

It is crucial, however, for corporations to provide language immersion courses for their employees before they transfer them to overseas positions. Alas, foreigners have almost come to expect that Americans won't know their language when they arrive.

As one who can speak seven languages on various levels -- from order-a-meal proficiency to fluency -- I have had a thousand experiences abroad of enormous goodwill, prompted by even the most fumbling attempts to speak the local language.
And as I know from my personal experience, such knowledge also helps one to do the job properly.
JOHN STORM ROBERTS Tivoli, N.Y., Oct. 24
